msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Former Prophets, the Book of Ruth, the Book of Esther, and some passages of the Book of Proverbs

ab.title: Ruth 1
ab.l: It came to pass in the days when the judges ruled, that there was a famine in the land, and a man of Beth-lehem- judah went to sojourn in the plain of Moab, he, and his wife, and his two sons with him.

And the name of the man was Elimelech, and the name of his wife Naomi, and the name of his two sons Mahlon and Chilion, Ephrathites of Beth-lehemjudah, and they came into the plain of Moab, and remained there.
And Elimelech the husband of Naomi died; and she was left, and her two sons.
And they took them wives of the women of Moab; the name of the one was Orpah, and the name of the other Ruth: and they dwelled there about ten years.
And Mahlon and Chilion died also both of them; and the woman was left without her two sons and her husband.
Then she arose and her daughters-in-law, to return from the plain of Moab: for she had heard in the plain of Moab how that the Lord had remembered his people in giving them bread.
So she set out from the place where she and her two daughters-in-law with her were, and they went on the way to return to the land of Judah.
And Naomi said to her two daughters-in-law, ‘Go, return each of you to her mother’s house: May the Lord deal kindly as you have dealt with the dead, and with me.
The Lord grant you that you may find rest, each of you in the house of her husband.’ And she kissed them; and they lifted up their voices, and wept.
And they said to her, ‘We will return with you to your people.

And Naomi said, ‘Return, my daughters: why will you go with me? Are there yet any more sons in my womb, that they may become
your husbands?
Return, my daughters, go, for I am too old to have a husband. If I should say, I have hope, if I should have a husband also tonight, and should also bear sons;

Would you have hope for them till they were grown? Would you be late for them, being not given to a husband? No, my daughters; it grieves me much for your sakes for the hand of the Lord has gone out against me.’
And they lifted up their voices, and wept again: and Orphah kissed her mother-in-law; but Ruth clung to her.
And she said, ‘Behold, your sister-in-law has gone back to her people, and to her god: return you after your sister-in-law.’
But Ruth said, ‘Do not beg me to leave you to return from following after you. For where you go I will go, and where you lodge I will lodge: your people are my people, and your God my God.
Where you die, there will I die, and there will I be buried: the Lord do so to me, and more also, if anything but death parts me and you.’
And she saw that she became strong in her willto go with her, she stopped speaking to her.
And they went on, two of them, until they came to Bethlehem. And the whole town was talking loudly about them, and said: ‘Is this Naomi?’
And she said to them, ‘Call me not Naomi, call me Mara for the powerful God has troubled me much.
I went away full and the Lord has brought me back empty: why call me Naomi, when the powerful has testified for me and has been bad for me?’

So Naomi returned, and Ruth the Moabitess, her daughter-in-law, with her, who returned out of the plain of Moab: and they came to Bethlehem
in the beginning of barley harvest.
